item.title: About Me
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
My name is Jorge Pedret and I'm a creative Front End Developer & Designer with 11 years of experience designing and writing web applications. I currently live in Vancouver, Canada, where I build websites for startups and small businesses. I'm a big fan of openness and open source code, these are some of the technologies I work with:
  • JavaScript/jQuery
  • CSS3
  • HTML5
  • WordPress
  • PHP
  • MySQL
  • CodeIgniter
Do you think I can help your business? [button link="/contact-me/" style="tick"]Send me an email[/button] You can find me posting stuff on Twitter & Google+, writing articles on Beans & Curry, drawing and sketching on Dribbble and Forrst & networking on LinkedIn.

item.title: How to Scare IE Users into Upgrading with only ONE Line of Code?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Simply put: [html] <!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">@import url(http://www.joelevi.com/securityupdate/bar.css);</style><div id="advBrowserWarning"><a href="http://www.joelevi.com/securityupdate/securityAlert.html"><b>WARNING!!!</b> Your version of Internet Explorer has known security issues! To protect your computer please correct this now. Click here for options...</a></div><![endif]--> [/html] This is a great idea! I just found this post that talks about a technique for scaring the crap out of IE6 users... Although is something I'm not going to apply in my websites (it'd be so funny though hahaha), it's a pretty nice way to make them migrate to a better browser: Check out this post here Enjoy! and comment if you're applying it to your website hehehe

item.title: Posting from my iphone
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: So I'm just testing this new wordpress feature that allows you to post from your mobile device... You only need to enable xml-rpc in your blog configuration, install the wordpress iPhone free application, enter your admin information and you are ready to post! You can also moderate comments, and manage your pages! It's pretty cool! I'll probably be posting comments from my mobile more often :)

item.title: Designing for the Social Web - Book Review
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I just finished reading a really really good book called 'Designing for the Social Web' written by Joshua Porter (@bokardo). By using real life examples he breaks down the steps needed to take users from being unaware of your web to being passionate users (your ultimate goal). The most important lessons I learned? If I would have only 2 seconds to explain to you the most important part of the book IMHO, I would say: "Identify your desired users and have an authentic conversation with them." Make it easy for your users to send you a feedback or to contact you and listen to what they have to say. At the end everything turns around the user: Design for signup, design for ongoing participation, design for collective intelligence, design for sharing, this are all tools/actions the user will be using/executing. Joshua creates a framework called AOF (Activities, Objects and Features), which sets what you should prioritize when you're in the designing/planning process. To wrap the idea in a few lines: Focus 90% of your energy in defining the main Activity you will be doing (what your users are/will be doing) and making sure it always kept in mind through the planning process.  Identify the Objects that people interact with while doing the main activity. Define the core Feature set after having an activity and objects defined, think of it as the actions people perform on the objects. What did I learn from the book?
  • I learned that the real value of Amazon is the products reviews section.
  • Everything that you think you know but you don't really apply it very much, he breaks it down and explains it with real life examples, helping you get a more solid concept of what you already know.
  • Your application is not based on the features it has, it's based on the main activity it supports. When you're thinking of your application, don't define it like this: It's going to have a blog, it will also support user registration and profiles pages, the user can subscribe to the news letters, etc. As the AOF method says, define your activity first and that should be the main thing.
  • Respect the power of an authentic conversation with your users. That's the path to create passionate users.
  • How to make the user feel unique and at the same time make him feel like he belongs to a common-likes group.
  • How to encourage your users to participate by reciprocity laverage.
  • How you create signup friction through forms and how you can reduce it (this section of the book was really good!).
  • How to measure your success with numbers (although is not very specific, it gives you a nice introduction and overview of it).
I'm currently reading a new book called 'Letting Go of the Words - Writing Web Content that Works' by Janice Redish, it seems pretty promising, I'll post my review as soon as I finish it (and a link to buy it from the amazon store so I make money *Muhuhuhahaha - Laughs with evilness*) . Have you read designing for the social web?

Tell me what you think about it! Did you hate it? Did you love it? What did you learn from it? What was your favorite part?

Want to read this book?

Write a comment if you have any questions about it, or if you want to know something in specific. If you're decided to get the book, get it here Designing for the Social Web, it's better than all the other places where you can get it. *Muhuhuhahaha - Laughs with evilness again!*

Have questions?

I'll be happy to help you, just post them as a comment and we'll discuss it!

Thanks very much for visiting and if you want to stay tunned on my latest projects, adventures and more, follow me on twitter. Cheers and keep your code clean!

item.title: Perfect web development environment
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
What am i going to talk about and what you'll learn A good development environment should allow you to make easy:
  • Prototyping
  • Talking to the client and your team
  • Designing
  • Turning your design to HTML/CSS
  • Testing your website functionality
  • Testing your website in multiple browsers
  • Delivering the final product
  • Being able to work from anywhere (like any great freelancer)
Although half of the items in this list can be achieved by having a strong computer, there are still some that can be made more fun just by making some changes in your development environment. Setting up a good development environment allows you to work more efficient and professionally; it helps you to deliver a more robust product and helps you understand how your design behaves in different platforms. After reading this article, you should be able to apply this techniques in your work place to improve:
  • Turning your design to HTML/CSS
  • Testing your website in multiple browsers
  • Testing your website's functionality
  • Being able to work from anywhere
Here I describe what has worked the best for me and how you can apply it. It's not perfect (yet), but it has helped me A LOT in testing, mobility and making my designs look good in multiple browsers. Result and advantages of working in this environment As a result you should have as many development computers as you want, with a web server installed and your development files in each one of them. I have an iMac and a Mackbook Pro for development; anytime I want or have to go out I would take the laptop, bring my portable hard drive and I'm ready to work from anywhere. You'll also have your testing computers that will have access to what you're working on, this way you can just turn to their keyboard, hit f5 and see the results of your changes. I find this way of testing more efficient than having 20 different browsers open in your computer and having to switch windows all the time. In my desk I have my development computer in front and the testing machines on the sides. What you'll need
  • As many computers as you can get with as many different operating systems as possible. (I currently only have three: a Windows Desktop, a Ubuntu laptop and an iMac) This computers will be for testing and development. For example: I have an imac and a macbook pro for development and the rest is for testing.
  • A network where you can see all the testing/development computers. If you don't have one, you only need to get a router and connect them.
  • A portable hard disk drive. I have an scandisk of 1 TB. The difference between external hard drive and portable hard drive is that the portable doesn't need a power source, it's given by the usb cable. So a portable hard drive adds way more mobility.
  • A big desk :-) (this is optional, but it adds comfort)
Step by step
  1. Make sure your portable hdd works on all your development computers. By work I mean, that you're able to read, write and execute files from it. I had problems with mine, but how to solve it depends on each model. just post a comment to see if I can help you.
  2. For each development computer, write down the path to access the portable hdd. In my macs it's /Volumes/DATA/ in my linux it's /mnt/DATA/ (or something like that) and windows it should be g:// or whatever unit letter it decides to assign to the media device. You're going to need this for configuring the http server later.
  3. Copy your web files (your document root) to the portable hdd into any folder. I have the in /www/
  4. Install your favorite http server (mine and a lot of people's favorite is Apache) in your development computers. We'll configure it later.
  5. For each development computer, create a virtual interface and write them down
  6. Add a virtual host to your apache config file like the following:
  7. Restart apache
  8. Test the results by going to your dev IP. If it works fine, go to the next computer (development or testing) and try to access it by the ip from the browser
Result Now you should be able to develop websites and test in different machines at the same time you're writing the code. Limitations
  • You can't access your testing computers when you are outside with your laptop development computer
  • There's a lot of configuring that I think can be reduce or automated, either by installing a DNS server or by a more automated apache configuration
  • You have to type your dev's IP in the testing computer which can get annoying, it would be better if you could type a name like dev1 or something like that. I think this can be achieved with a DNS server or maybe some advanced router feature.
Any comments? Do you like this idea? Do you have any comments to make, or can you help me make it better?

item.title: How to write effective web content?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Content is why people come to your website

Content is the reason why people visit your website. They are searching for information. If they can't quickly find what they're looking for, they leave. Learning how to make your content easy to access, helps your visitors find what they're looking for. They don't want welcome messages or animated splash pages. They want to find what they came for... and quickly. For writing effective content you must get in your visitors mind. Most of us believe that we know who our users are; We believe that we know what they're thinking. Unfortunately, we don't realize this is false until we get closer to them; until we study them, their needs and their day to day life. To understand your visitors you must create personas. A persona is an imaginary human created by you. This persona has:
  • Name
  • Age
  • Occupation
  • Needs
  • Skills
  • And even a picture.
By creating this persona, your mind leaves its own ego and starts thinking according to this imaginary person. The final goal of creating personas is to help you understand your visitor's questions and create real life scenarios.

Everything on your website should fulfill a scenario

After you create a list of personas, it's time to think of possible scenarios. Scenarios are short stories that give you a good sense of the people who come to your site; What they want to do at your website. "Scenarios tell you the conversations people want to start" - Janice Redish, Letting go of the Words
I'm traveling from the U.S. to India next month. Do I need a visa?
My niece will be two years old next week. I'm looking for a cute dress to send to her.
If your content is not fulfilling any scenario, what's the reason of having it? Change it to fulfill a scenario or delete it.

Breaking down long content helps visitors organize your website's ideas

Whenever you see a "wall of text" keep in mind that:
  • Your users won't read it, or
  • It will be a pain in the butt to read (and they'll be swearing at you for making it so hard to read).
Break "walls of text" by making good use of these elements:
  • Lists
  • Tables
  • Simplified text
  • Sub headings
Lists If you find yourself separating items by comas or enumerating items, convert those items into a list.
  • It helps your visitors skim
  • Makes the content easy to grab and go.
  • Saves your users from having to create a mental list.
  • Help visitors find the item they're looking for faster.
Tables Consider using tables when you need to compare numbers, have series of "if, then" or similar situations.
  • Tables help you organize information in a more visual way
  • It makes the content easy to grab and go.
  • Visitors look for their question on the left column and when they find it, they look for the answer on the right column(s).
Simplified Text It helps users understand what you mean by just reading it once. Simplify your text following these tips:
  • Remove any welcome message. If you don't want to remove it, think of what real life scenario the welcome message is fulfilling. Usually your answer will be none.
  • Remove any fluff words that don't mean anything. Words like 'simply', 'basically', 'due to the fact that', 'at this point in time' can be completely removed or changed for a simpler word. Reading your sentences without fluff words sound a lot simpler We are simply the best drug store. Our installations basically have all kinds of medicines for you.
  • Change complicated or technical words for very simple ones.
  • Write one to three short sentences for each paragraph, no more than that.
  • Try to avoid using comas. Break the sentence into two or more sentences instead.
Sub headings Also called sub titles. This helps users by telling them what they're going to find after the heading. They can also make a general meaning of your document by only reading the sub headings. Sub headings can be formatted like:
  • Questions (E.g: "Why is good content necessary?") Use questions when your user comes to the site with questions. It's a very good technique for clicking with your visitor.
  • Statements (E.g: "Good content helps visitors find what they're looking for") This technique helps to get a better understanding of what's below the heading. Notice the main headings of this article are formated like statements.
  • Action Phrases (E.g: "Write good content by following these basic rules") Use this technique when you want to encourage your user to do something or follow a list of steps.
  • Nouns (E.g: "Good Content Writing") This format can be used in some specific cases; most of the time for labels. Nouns are not conversational, unlike questions, statements or action phrases.

Naming your links efficiently saves visitors from feeling lost

Naming links is one of the most important tasks while developing content. If you've read the phrase 'click here', you've seen bad link names. Knowing what to put between the <a> tag is very simple, just follow these rules:
  • No 'read more', 'click here', 'more' links Users usually skim through the text by jumping from one link to the next. Having a more descriptive link would help users know where that link is going to take them. By having a 'read more' link, you obligate them to read what is before and after the link to understand what it is.
  • Have links match your page titles If visitors click on a link called 'How to find a girlfriend' they want the page where they are redirected to be titled 'How to find a girlfriend'. This not only supports consistency through your website but it also makes the user know right away that he's in the right place.
  • Use your visitors words Avoid using your website marketing lingo for links. If you create a new section called 'volcano power', give the link a more descriptive name. Use your visitor's words. Users won't understand what you mean until after they click the link.
  • Use action phrases for links This is a great technique to encourage your users to do something. For example: If you're linking to a page where users can write their own comment, don't name the link "comments". Name it something like "write a comment" or "send us a comment". Whatever works best.

"Inverted pyramid" text makes visitors interested enough to continue reading

The inverted pyramid text is the total opposite of how we were taught in school. For this method you write the key message first. And you expand the subjects as you write. This technique is frequently used by journalists in newspapers. Writing this way helps visitors quickly identify if they're really interested or if they've read enough and want to stop. There's a similar technique for introducing new concepts to users. Let's call it the known->unknown technique. To use the known->unknown technique you start the paragraph with something the users already know and introduce something new in the second sentence. Then, in the start of the next paragraph you use the information that you introduced in the second sentence of the previous paragraph. It's easier to see it in action than to explain it. I'm going to use an example from Janice Redish's book, Letting go of the Words (again): Notice the first line of the first paragraph talks about something the user would already know if he's looking to import yams into the US. The second line of the first paragraph introduces new information, indicating the yams need to be fumigated. In the second paragraph, fumigation is already old information for the user, so it's used to start the paragraph. Then the second sentence introduces new information. Using this method makes users feel a lot more comfortable with what they're reading and saves them from feeling lost in the process. It also helps educate them about unknown subjects.

Where can I find more about content writing?

Most (if not all) of this information was taken from Janice Redish book, Letting go of the words. It's an excellent book that I recommend all web developers and everybody related to read. Of course there is a lot more detail in the book. It will teach you, using a lot of real life examples, what I just mentioned here. My writing skills still suck, but at least now I'm able to identify bad content and improve it by 10000%. I also recommend that you read DON'T MAKE ME THINK by Steve Krug. A really well done book that talks about helping your users understand what the hell you're trying to say and lots about web usability.
item.excerpt:encoded:
Content is the reason why people visit your website. They are searching for information. If they can't quickly find what they're looking for, they leave.
Learning how to make your content easy to access, helps your visitors find what they're looking for. They don't want welcome messages or animated splash pages. They want to find what they came for... and quickly.

item.title: CSS won't style my HTML5 markup in Internet Explorer!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
You built your whole website using html5 new shiny tags, you're so proud of yourself, it looks great in your development browser!! It's finally time to give it a test in Internet Explorer, let's see how it looks like... WHAT??? That looks a lot worst than I was expecting... What the heck is going on? You try changing your css, but explorer doesn't change at all... You verify if you're actually working on the right file, and yes in deed, you are. You try to add some basic css properties, but again, it doesn't change a bit. The problem is...

Internet Explorer completely ignores html5 new tags

OMG! Until when this stupid browser is going to give me head aches - you say out loud. At this point you have two options:
  1. Change your entire markup and css to use old tags
  2. Use Remy Sharp's fix. The only downsize: It completely depends on Javascript
IE simply ignores all the elements it doesn't recognize, regardless of CSS. By using javascript's function document.createElement(), we iterate through the markup and recreate all the tags that are not recognized by IE.

Quick copy/paste solution

Here is the code taken directly from Remy's site: [javascript] <!--[if IE]> <script src="http://html5shim.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/html5.js"></script> <![endif]--> [/javascript] I'm thinking it might be a good idea to condition the code to IE versions lower than 8, since IE9 will have html5 support and it might be coming soon, but that's up to you: [javascript] <!--[if lte IE 8]> <script src="http://html5shim.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/html5.js"></script> <![endif]--> [/javascript] I feel stupid for not being aware and for not testing earlier in IE. It took me a while to figure out what was going on. Get more information from this sites: http://net.tutsplus.com/tutorials/html-css-techniques/how-to-make-all-browsers-render-html5-mark-up-correctly-even-ie6/ http://remysharp.com/2009/01/07/html5-enabling-script/
item.excerpt:encoded:
You built your whole website using html5 new shiny tags, you're so proud of yourself, it looks great in your development browser. Time to give it a test in Internet Explorer to see what it looks like. It looks a lot worst than you was expecting... What the heck is going on?
Make html5 work under ie6, ie7 & ie8 by adding this small JavaScript code.

item.title: Fundamental Guidelines Of E-Commerce Checkout Design
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
1. Your Checkout Process Should Be Completely Linear
  2. Add Descriptions To Form Field Labels
  3. Avoid Contextual Words Like “Continue”
  4. Visually Reinforce All Sensitive Fields On The Payment Page
  5. Don’t Use An “Apply” Button In Your Form
  6. Format Field For Expiration Date Exactly As It Appears On Credit Card
  7. Use Only One Column For Form Fields
  8. Use Shipping Address As Billing Address By Default
  9. Use Clear Error Indications
  10. Registration Should Be Optional

item.title: Notes from Building Content Strategy Using Information Architecture
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
There are two types of clients:
  • By the number people
  • Gut reaction people

Approaching by-the-number clients

Calculate how much money their wasting by calculating the inefficiency of the current system. How much time employees loose because of  poor navigation and lack of design standards. Tools for geting quantitative data:
  • Usability Testing — Test your site with 5 people, fix the major issues and test again
  • Google Analytics — Site metrics (http://google.com/analytics)
  • Crazy Egg — Heatmap application (http://www.crazyegg.com/)
  • Userfly — Record and replay interactions made by your visitors (http://userfly.com/)
  • Feedback Army — $15 for 10 remote usability test (http://www.feedbackarmy.com/)
  • 5 second test — How your page to testers for 5 seconds and get their feedback (http://fivesecondtest.com/)
  • User Testing — http://www.usertesting.com/
  • ClickTale — Heatmap application (http://www.clicktale.com/)

Approaching gut-reaction clients

Tell them a good story, show them how their site can go bad, worst case scenarios, make them feel like their missing something out!

Tools for Information Architecture

  • Bubbl.us — Mapping tool to layout site structure (https://bubbl.us/)
  • Axure — Dynamic visualizations, details and diagram of flows (http://www.axure.com/)
  • HotGloo — Wireframing tool (http://www.hotgloo.com/)

Where to get started?

  • Check for free community templates online
  • State the goals of the website, what is this site going to accomplish
  • Structure the sitemap
  • Wireframe the home page with the primary navigation, content areas and call to actions

Wordpress Solutions & Plugins

  • Related posts plugin — show related posts
  • Google custom search — nasty, google formated page
  • Search Everything — select what you can
  • Search suggest — real time search suggest
  • Breadcrumb NavXT — simple breadcrumbs plugin
  • Smart 404 — it returns content that might be related to the non existing page
  • Dagon Design Sitemap Generator — Sitemap generator

item.title: Notes From "Extending WordPress Themes Without Plugins"
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Cameron advises agains adding pluggins for everything, why?
  • Take ownership of your code, know what your site is really doing
  • Build your own library of code and techniques for future projects
  • "Make WordPress fo crazy things nobody else has thought of yet" — Sometimes there isn't a plugin that does exactly what you want.
  • Makes a great topic for a WordCamp talk (haha)

Benefits of taking control of your code

  • Less bloat better performance
  • Cleaner and simpler HTML/CSS/JS
  • Plugins can confuse your visitors

Some benefits of using plugins

  • Not always worth custom coding one-offs
  • Some pluggins fo offer great functionality out-of-the-box
  • Budget / Time constraints
  • Standardization
  • Upgrade compatibility — Some plugins are ver well maintained and are compatible with newer versions of WP

Examples & Interesting Ideas

  • Extend WordPress's image handling, galleries — This section can be improved a lot. It's not intuitive.
  • AJAX-ify parts of your theme and functions — Using AJAX to load sections of your site, instead of loading everything at the same time.
  • Integrate a WP site with web services APIs — Integrating WordPress with external services, i.e.: Interacting with a CRM API

The (Image) Slider

Cameron showed a sample of a slider that he created for one of his clients. Not sure what was his point in showing all his code and the examples. It's simple to

The map

He showed a 3 cool examples of custom made map applications that he'd developed in the past. He promised to post links to the examples. (Will update when he does)

The AJAX

He ran out of time to talk about AJAX-ify, but he showed some cool examples of posts that load on-the-fly with a modal window. Follow Cameron Cavers on Twitter

item.title: Notes for "WordPress & E-commerce"
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Justin talked about the main three plugins for WordPress e-commerce:
  • Cart66
  • Shopp
  • Wordpress Ecommerce

Shopp

http://shopplugin.net/

Pros

  • Very solid plugin, backed up by strong businesses
  • 7 cool widgets
  • Payment gateways integration, you can download additional ones for a small fee
  • Good support for inventory & stock alert
  • Complete shipping modules
  • Supports product variations
  • Promotions
  • Shortcodes for products, categories, etc.

Cons

  • Doesn't follow coding conventions, they have they're own conventions.
  • Doesn't use WordPress features for functionality.

Cart66

http://cart66.com/

Pros

  • Support most payment gateways, only pluggin that supports Authorize.net natively
  • Good inventory management
  • Complete shipping module
  • Promotions support
  • Shortcodes for shopping cart, products, category, etc.
  • SEO — Automatically integrated with mayor SEO plugins like All-in-one SEO
  • Very solid documentation and customer service
  • Great support for digital products
  • GPL

Cons

  • Poor implementation for product variations, hard to follow syntax and feels incomplete
  • They fall behind on the widgets, only comes with one.
  • Doesn't use WordPress features for functionality, has its own code convenctions.
  • Only 4 filters, so it doesn't allow for much customization
  • Poor Internationalization
  • Not too many widgets

WPEC (WordPress eCommerce)

http://wordpress.org/extend/plugins/wp-e-commerce/

Pros

  • Lots of widgets — best seller, recent purchases, categories, child categories, etc.
  • Payment Gateways — Supports most payment gateways
  • Good inventory management
  • Very complete shipping modules
  • Supports Product Variations
  • Support Shortcodes
  • SEO
  • Used to suck before, but now it's getting awesome after 3.8 was launched
  • Tons of actions and filter (+180) (+200 counting WordPress natives)
  • Internationalization support, compatible with WordPress native functionality
  • 8 widgets
  • Great Community

Cons

  • Lots of legacy bloat for backward compatibility

Contact Justin Sainton

@JS_Zao http://zaowebdesign.com/ office@zaowebdesign.com

item.title: My Notes for "Javascript & Wordpress"
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Allen Pike packed JavaScript in a 20 minute talk, describing the similarities and differences with other programming languages. [box]Download the presentation slides: [button link="http://www.antipode.ca/slides/tackling_js.pdf" size="medium" style="download"]Download[/button][/box] Javascript is the most widely deployed language ion the world. People are creating more apps in JavaScript than before because:
  • Computers are faster
  • All the raising JavaScript libraries that standardize and make JS a lot cooler

JavaScript and PHP similarities

  • Dynamic and loose
  • C-like syntax
  • Curly braces
  • if, else, for, etc.
  • Garbage collection
  • Post-web

JavaScript and PHP differences

  • Everything is an object
  • Objects and inheritance
  • Scope and this

Lint

  • Bad parts are simple mistakes
  • JSLint, JavaScript Lint, JSHint
  • Auto lint

Wordpress

The function wp_enque script helps you load common libraries like jQuery, Scriptaculous, jQUI, TinyMCE, and it lets let load your own js files. You can also specify if you want your files to load in the footer to optimize loading speed :-). Thanks @apike for answering my question.

JavaScript Libaries

  • DOM (jQuery, Prototype) — Most popular libraries for manipulating the DOM
  • MVC (Backbone, JSMBC, Spine) — Libraries that helps you write JavaScript in a more organized and MVC way
  • Everything (ExtJS, YUI, SproutCore)  — They do everything
  • microjs.com — Recently launched library where you can chose what you want

Debugging JavaScript

  • console.log(), and console.trace()
  • stack traces, step debugging

Other resources for learning JavaScript

  • Learning Advanced JavaScript — http://ejohn.org/apps/learn/
  • Douglas Crockford — javascript.crockford.com
  • VanJS: — vanjs.com

Get in touch with Allen Pike

www.antipode.ca www.steamclocksw.com @apike

item.title: Read this before hiring your next developer / designer
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: [quote]So what should a real interview consist of? Let me offer a humble proposal: don’t interview anyone who hasn’t accomplished anything. Ever. Certificates and degrees are not accomplishments; I mean real-world projects with real-world users. There is no excuse for software developers who don’t have a site, app, or service they can point to and say, “I did this, all by myself!” in a world where Google App Engine and Amazon Web Services have free service tiers, and it costs all of $25 to register as an Android developer and publish an app on the Android Market.[/quote]

item.title: Finding Placeholder Images for your Designs
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Here are 3 tools that I've been using lately to show placeholder images in the sites I design: Lorempixum, Flickholdr & Placehold.it

Lorempixum

http://lorempixum.com/ It was recently launched , but I've found it to be one of the best tools so far. You can specify the size, the category and if you want it colored or black & white. Here are some examples of how to use it, simply put this in the src parameter of your img tag: [code] http://lorempixum.com/400/200 http://lorempixum.com/g/400/200 http://lorempixum.com/400/200/sports http://lorempixum.com/400/200/sports/1 [/code]

Flickholdr

http://flickholdr.com/ Works the same way as Lorempixum, but looks for the images in Flickr. It makes sure that the images' copyright allow you to use them anywhere. The thing that I like about Flickholdr that Lorempixum doesn't have, is that you can choose your own tags, instead of using fixed tags. I had a couple of issues with Flickholdr's interface to generate images, but other than that it works like a charm. Here are some examples of how to use it. Again, simply put this in the src parameter of your img tag: [code] http://flickholdr.com/200/300 http://flickholdr.com/200/300/sea,sun http://flickholdr.com/200/300/sea,sun/bw http://flickholdr.com/200/300/sea,sun/1 [/code]

Placehold.it

http://placehold.it/ And finally... placehold.it. It's a much simpler version compared to the last two tools, it's a solid color image instead of a picture. You can use it when you just need to mark a place as an image placeholder, or if you are just doing a website's wireframe, etc. Here are some examples of how to use it. Again, simply put this in the src parameter of your img tag: [code] http://placehold.it/350x150 http://placehold.it/300x100/000/fff/&text=Custom%20Text http://placehold.it/600x200/000/fff.png [/code]

item.title: Resizing WordPress Images with AJAX Thumbnail Rebuild
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is a quick post on how to resize images from WordPress media library after they've been uploaded. [box type=note]

In a rush?

  1. Download and install the AJAX Thumbnail Rebuild plugin on your WordPress site
  2. Go to "Tools > Rebuild Thumbnails" and follow the steps
[/box]

What's the current problem?

Once you've uploaded images to the media library, it's impossible to resize them to the new sizes that you've added using add_image_size() function.

How does AJAX Thumbnail Rebuild solves the problem?

Although the name is a little bit misleading, ATR (AJAX Thumbnail Rebuild) goes through all the images that you have uploaded before and creates the new image sizes that you've added using the add_image_size() function. Other similar plugins used to do all this process in the backend, which often timed out for large image libraries. That's where ATR came up with a way to do it using AJAX and that's why the plugin name is AJAX Thumbnail Rebuild.

How to use it?

  1. Add the image sizes that you're going to use across your site using add_image_sizes() WordPress function
  2. Download and install the AJAX Thumbnail Rebuild plugin on your WordPress site
  3. Go to "Tools > Rebuild Thumbnails"
  4. Select the thumbnail sizes that you want to re-generate and click "Regenerate all Thumbnails"
This is a great plugin and its functionality should really be considered to be included in WordPress.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi, I used this plugin before, but now it stopped working and just gives error 500. Any clues on how I can diagnose this ?

There are lots of reasons what could be causing this 500 error. If you really need to get it working, go to the plugin directory and start studying the way it works. Then start debugging line by line and trying to figure out where the code is breaking.
You can debug using a script like the one below. Simply go line by line (using your smart programmer skills) and trying find where it breaks. [php]die('<pre>'.var_export($var, true).'</pre>');[/php]
If you're not a developer then I suggest to either get a developer or re-upload the images that you wanted to get resized.
Hope this helps!

I drop a leave a response when I especially enjoy a article on a site or if I have something to contribute to the conversation. Usually it's a result of the sincerness displayed in the article I read. And on this post Resizing WordPress Images with AJAX Thumbnail Rebuild | Jorge Pedret. I was actually excited enough to drop a leave a responsea response :-) I do have some questions for you if you don't mind. Is it simply me or does it give the impression like a few of the responses appear like written by brain dead individuals? :-P And, if you are writing at additional places, I'd like to follow you. Would you make a list the complete urls of your shared sites like your twitter feed, Facebook page or linkedin profile?
Asking questions are genuinely pleasant thing if you are not understanding something fully, but this piece of writing presents good understanding even.

item.title: Get pages by template name in WordPress
item.dc:creator: admin

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Totally AWESOME!! Thank you so much for sharing, you're the best!!
My pleasure! Happy to hear that is helping somebody :-) Cheers.
I put this code exactly as its shown, only replacing the page-quote.php with my own template file. But still the page is blank.

Hi Alyssa, could you post a link to your code and tell me what you're trying to do.
Make sure the template file is in the root of your template (i.e.: /wp-content/themes/<your_template>/page-template.php) Make sure there is at least one page created with that template assigned. Check for typos (stupid suggestion, I'm sure you already did) and that the code is being executed.
Works perfectly for me ! It's exactly what I needed, thanks
You helped me out, too... thank you!

Yes I am positive- the template is product.php and there are over 500 pages with this template
http://www.kccaribbeanservices.com/new
Thanks for the tip, much appreciated :).

Hi I thought I replied to you before. The link is http://www.kccaribbeanservices.com/latest
Actually It works with some page templates and not with others but I'm not sure why. The template that isn't working is being used on over 200 published pages. I double checked spelling and everything is correct. I am completely baffled!

wow I have figured out why it's not working but cannot fix it... the templates that work are only the templates that have no parent page. But all the pages with this template need to have parent pages. Why does having a parent to the page prevent this code from working?
Hey Alyssa, thanks for posting a solution for the problem :-) I'm happy you got it working.
Thanx Jorge and Alyssa! ‘hierarchical’ => 0 was the extra magic
So glad I was able to help someone! Now another question- any idea how to add pagination to this?

Jorge, a suggestion: you might want to edit your post to indicate Alyssa's discovery. I think it's worth noting as I almost gave up on this solution until I read her notes. And thank you for the article!

Is this possible?

item.title: Placeholder text for Gravity Form input elements
item.dc:creator: admin
item.excerpt:encoded: Surprisingly GravityForms hasn't implemented the placeholder feature yet. I know they have plans on doing so soon, but we need a solution while we wait for that. I came up with this quick solution using only GF filters and jQuery. Check it out!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Jorge, you are a genius!
Your solution is brilliant. You just saved me a LOT of time. Thank you, Matth
@Matth Thanks for your comments :-) Happy to see that it's helping somebody!

Seems to work well, although when a required field is blank, and you submit the form, the placeholder text disappears... Which is a bit of an issue if you are using the placeholder text instead of field labels.
Thanks Jorge!! Just what I was looking for. I can't believe Gravity Forms doesn't have this yet.
@Nick I'm happy it helped you! I'm sure they have it in mind for the next updates :-). Cheers!

Hey Darrell, I'm not sure why this is happening. If you send me the export file for the form that you're working on I could take a look at it.
Or if you solved it already, you're welcome to post the code here for everybody to see it :-)
Cheers!

Hello! I'm trying to implement your code — it's loaded into my functions.php file, and everything seems to fire, but I'm not getting any of the placeholders in my form. I looked at the post-Jquery input fields, and one looks like this, as I would have expected it to be injected into the value:
The form is located on a test server at http://pridehouston.cccomm.us/contact
If you could provide any assistance, I would appreciate it!

Nice for you to repost this solution, however, it doesn't appear to work in IE 8? There is the placeholder.js that does work at https://github.com/Jayphen/placeholder though I don't know how to incorporate with this above function in the functions.php file. Any ideas how to add the placholder.js to this awesome function for gravity forms to get it to work on IE 8? Thanks!

This is tremENdous!!! Thanks! You might have saved me hours!!
!!!

Hi Angela, thanks for your question! I'm taking advantage of the placeholder property used only in modern browsers. The library that you posted would work perfectly in this case. Just make sure Jayphen's library is being included after my code.
I just saw that you posted a solution in your blog, I'm updating this post with a link to your post for people with the same question. :-)

Hi Joe,
Great snippet, you should consider to submit it at http://wp-snippets.com. Anyway I had a small problem when I load the jQuery in the footer instead of header. Then it does not work, so I had to switch that the head instead as I cannot figure out how to load gravity forms scripts in footer. Anyway good job, keep it on and thanks! :-)
BTW - this does not work when you post the form (through AJAX) and there are errors. Then the placeholder's are gone..
Wahey! Brilliant stuff, worked a treat. Cheers!

item.title: Post of the day: Characters brainstorming
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I'm creating a mascot character for a client's business, and this is part of the brainstorming process: One of my favorite steps of this job :-). Here's one of the characters that I came up with during the brainstorming session: For generating ideas my favorite thing to do is draw for hours whatever comes into my head, even if I think it's stupid or it's not going to work. One of those drawings will spark a great idea! The biggest idea blocker is being scared of what other people might say about what you're doing. Just let your mind be free and great inspiration will come to you! As always, comment if you have something to say :-) P.S.: I'm going to stop calling this posts, "post of the day". I'm seriously having a hardtime finding time to do something everyday, but I still post at least twice a week. You can still find my work in progress posts by its tag here http://jorgepedret.com/tag/daily-posts/

item.title: Separating Photoshop Layer Styles Into Their Own Layer — A Method & Craft Video
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Check out Luke Holder from Method & Craft on "Layer Style Jailbreaking". He show us how to make Photoshop Layer Styles separate into their own layer and some reasons why we want to do that. This is a technique I've never seen before, so if you don't know what I'm talking about, just check out the video. Here's a quick step-by-step list:
  1. In Photoshop, select a layer with styles assigned to it.
  2. On the main menu, go to Layer > Layer Style > Create Layer (Click OK on the message prompt).
  3. Now all the styles are layers!
item.excerpt:encoded: Check out Luke Holder from Method & Craft on "Layer Style Jailbreaking". He show us how to make Photoshop Layer Styles separate into their own layer and some reasons why we want to do that.

item.title: SEO for non-dicks
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The key thing to understand is that the rules of SEO aren’t magic or arbitrary. They’re based on the goals of a search engine, which is to find relevant results. Relevance implies genuineness, and genuineness implies trust. So, shockingly, you should try to make your site’s content trustworthy, genuine and relevant. All of the rules have come about due to their utility in detecting those three positive metrics. Good SEO is a by-product of not being a dick on the internet. Matt Legend Gemmell ~ SEO for Non-dicks
I couldn't agree more with Matt. I'd add that some of the core SEO rules are also based on how usable and accessible the site is.

item.title: How to translate WordPress' admin to a different language?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
While traveling in Venezuela, I was helping a friend setup his first WordPress site. He loved every single part of it, except that it was all in English and he wanted to see it in Spanish. Que problem-o. Using a different language for WordPress' admin, was something I've always wanted to learn, so I started looking around and I couldn't believe how easy it was...

1. Download the language files

Go to this url http://codex.wordpress.org/WordPress_in_Your_Language and search for the language that you're looking for:
  1. Find the language that you're looking for (i.e.: es_ES)
  2. Download the whole WordPress package for that language
  3. Uncompress the downloaded .zip file
  4. All the language files will be under the /wp-content/languages/ directory

2.Move the languages files to your current WordPress installation

Copy the language files from the previously uncompressed package (from /wp-content/languages/) and move them to /wp-content/languages/ in your current WordPress installation.

3. Change the wp-config.php file

Go to the /wp-config.php file in your current WordPress installation and change the WPLANG constant to your language. This is what mine looks like: [php] define('WPLANG', 'es_ES'); [/php]

That's it!

Reload your admin panel and it should now be translated to your own language (or your clients'). While researching this stuff, I also found an amazing plugin to manually translate WordPress templates that use the __() and _e() l10n's functions. If you don't know what I'm talking about check this out http://codex.wordpress.org/I18n_for_WordPress_Developers. I'll be writing a post about that soon, so stay close if this is something you're interested in!
item.excerpt:encoded:

item.title: Cloning a remote WordPress site in your local computer
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is a trick that I usually use when I need to clone an existing WordPress installation in my local computer.
  1. Clone all the remote WordPress files in your local computer.
  2. Clone the remote WordPress database into your local computer.
  3. Update the wp-config.php file with your local MySQL access info and database name.
  4. Replace the old domain with the new domain in your local MySQL by running this commands:
[sql] UPDATE wp_options SET option_value = REPLACE(option_value, 'http://old.domain.com', 'http://new.domain.com'); UPDATE wp_posts SET post_content = REPLACE(post_content, 'http://old.domain.com', 'http://new.domain.com'); [/sql]
item.excerpt:encoded: This is a trick that I usually use when I need to clone an existing WordPress installation in my local computer.

item.title: Connecting existing git repository with an existing remote github repository
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This often happens to me whenever I start a new project:
  1. I start working locally on a brand new project
  2. I go to GitHub and create a new repository for my project
  3. Confused, start Google-ing how to connect the two of them

How do I connect them?

Here's what you need to do to connect your local git repo with your remote github repo: [code] cd /my/local/project/path/ git init git remote add --track master origin git@github.com:jorgepedret/foo.git [/code]
  1. CD into your local project directory
  2. Run git init, if you haven't ran it yet
  3. Connect the remote repo with your local repo
Done! Now you can commit your changes, pull rebase and then push to your remote repository [code] git add . git commit -m "Initial commit" git pull --rebase origin master git push origin master [/code]

Another way to do it

Here's another way to connect your local repo with a remote github repo:
  1. Rename your local project directory
  2. Clone your GitHub repo specifying the original directory
  3. Move the original content to the new repository
  4. Delete the temporary directory created in line 1
[code] mv my_project my_project_temp git clone https://github.com/jorgepedret/foo.git my_project cp -r ./my_project_temp/. my_project rm -r ./my_project_temp [/code]

What's the correct way to do it?

The correct way to do it is to start your GitHub repository before starting to code. That way you can simply use git clone and then just start working on it. That's it! Thanks to Caius Theory and Ciarán Walsh for helping me find a solution for this problem.
